channel.title: Interleaved RSS Feed
channel.description: This is an interleaved feed of the most recent entries from each RSS source, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: Why a 5% 10-year Treasury yield could be a buying opportunity
item.description: Investors may look back and ‚Äúsee points in time‚Äù when Treasury yields were approaching 5% and investors should have been buying, according to PGIM‚Äôs head of global bonds.

item.title: Amazon workers in North Carolina to vote on unionization next month
item.description: If the election is successful, the warehouse would be only the second Amazon site in the U.S. to unionize.

item.title: Thousands flee as wildfires burn out of control and destroy homes across the Los Angeles area
item.description: Wildfires tore across the Los Angeles area with devastating force Wednesday after setting off a desperate escape from burning homes through flames and winds.

item.title: Will the stock market be open tomorrow? As Jimmy Carter is laid to rest, the U.S. will observe a National Day of Mourning.
item.description: The U.S. will honor former President Jimmy Carter, who died on Dec. 29 at age 100, with an official state funeral on Thursday, Jan. 9.

item.title: Why Trump's pursuit of Greenland could be cheered on by Russia
item.description: President-elect Donald Trump's ongoing pursuit of Greenland may have raised the hackles of Denmark, but his territorial ambitions might find support in Russia.

item.title: Stocks edge lower as Wall Street struggles to recover from sell-off: Live updates
item.description: U.S. stocks hovered below the flatline Wednesday following a sharp decline in Big Tech names during the previous session.

item.title: Albertsons profit beat overshadows a sales miss as it readies to go it alone
item.description: Albertsons Cos. Inc.‚Äôs stock rose 3.6% early Wednesday, after the grocery chain beat profit estimates for its fiscal third quarter, offsetting a small revenue miss.

item.title: Private sector companies added 122,000 jobs in December, less than expected, ADP says
item.description: Job creation eased more than expected in December while wages grew at the slowest pace in nearly 3¬Ω years.

item.title: Why Trump's pursuit of Greenland could be cheered on by Russia
item.description: President-elect Donald Trump's ongoing pursuit of Greenland may have raised the hackles of Denmark, but his territorial ambitions might find support in Russia.

item.title: Treasury yield curve may be steepening for all the wrong reasons
item.description: Investors continued to sell off long-dated U.S. government maturities Wednesday morning, sending 20- and 30-year yields further into their highest levels in more than a year on lingering concerns about inflation and the possible impacts of the incoming Trump administration‚Äôs policies.

item.title: British luxury carmaker Rolls-Royce says super rich fueling a demand boom for bespoke models
item.description: BMW-owned Rolls Royce Motor Cars, like other luxury car brands, has seen an uptick in demand for bespoke and complex car models in recent months.

item.title: Trump could declare national economic emergency to justify universal tariffs, CNN reports
item.description: The president-elect is looking at utilizing the International Economic Emergency Powers Act to implement his plan for tariffs on imports.

item.title: Nvidia‚Äôs stock bounces as analysts show why the future looks brighter than ever
item.description: Nvidia‚Äôs talk of huge market opportunities in autonomous driving and robotics is ‚Äúpotentially comforting for investors thinking about what might come next for the company,‚Äù an analyst says.

item.title: Mortgage rates hit highest level since July, crushing application demand
item.description: Total mortgage application volume dropped 3.7% compared with the previous week.

item.title: Quantum stocks like Rigetti plunge after Nvidia's Huang says the computers are 15 to 30 years away
item.description: Quantum computing stocks dropped Wednesday after Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang declared that useful quantum computers are likely decades in the future.
